I know! Rendezvous date is today!

I can't watch right now cause I'm at work but I swear as soon as I get home I'm checking the ESA website for news and video.
As well as having no gravity, roids in KSP - even the biggest E class - are a tiny fraction of the size of the comet with which Rosetta has just rendezvoused.
can anyone explain those triangular "leg" maneuvers before they approach the comet?
They're building a high definition surface map from all possible angles under all possible lighting conditions.
